item.title: Building GitHub with Ruby on Rails
item.description: GitHub.com is written using Ruby on Rails and maintained by over a thousand engineers with almost 2 million lines of code.

item.title: Ask Wirecutter: Can you recommend a not-smart TV for me?
item.description: Wirecutter suggests securing smart TVs instead of finding non-smart options due to privacy concerns.

item.title: Codeberg â€“ Fast open source alternative to GitHub
item.description: Codeberg.org is a free and open-source software collaboration platform and Git hosting run by its users via a non-profit organization in Berlin.

item.title: Perennial rice: Plant once, harvest again & again
item.description: Scientists have created perennial rice strains that stay productive and regrow after every harvest, resulting in huge environmental benefits, a lower carbon footprint, healthier soil, and farmers not having to resow.

item.title: 60M Americans have taxes so simple the IRS could do them automatically
item.description: At least 41% of American households, or 62 million tax filing units, could have their entire tax returns handled by the IRS through "pre-populated returns" with no further intervention necessary.

item.title: We need to tell people ChatGPT will lie to them, not debate linguistics
item.description: The article discusses the issues surrounding large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, which can lie to people and have bugs that resist fixing.

item.title: Twitter won't allow retweeting tweets linking to Substack
item.description: Twitter has begun restricting tweets containing links to Substack.com in response to Substack's announcement of a new product, Notes, which will directly compete with Twitter.

item.title: Western Digital cloud services down for 4 days
item.description: Western Digital experienced an outage that started on April 2nd, impacting services including My Cloud, My Cloud Home, SanDisk ibi, and other related products, with an update posted on April 3rd.

item.title: How does database sharding work?
item.description: The article delves into database sharding, explaining the advantages of scaling-out instead of scaling-up with various sharding schemes and algorithms discussed.

item.title: NZ's biggest data breach shows retention is the sleeping giant of data security
item.description: Over one million New Zealand drivers' licenses and passports were exposed in the Latitude Financial data breach; some records were up to 18 years old.

item.title: U.S. & China wage war beneath the waves over internet cables
item.description: US and China are in a battle over undersea cables that transmit everything from emails to military secrets.

item.title: Why did Phreesia share my medical data after I opted out?
item.description: A report highlights medical companies sharing patient data without consent.

item.title: JavaScript-algorithms: Algorithms & data structures implemented in JavaScript
item.description: JavaScript-Algorithms is a comprehensive repository of popular algorithms and data structures implemented in JavaScript, organized by topic and paradigm.

item.title: SpaceX closing in on first Starship Super Heavy launch
item.description: SpaceX plans first launch of full-scale Starship vehicle later in April, pending regulatory approval; the Federal Aviation Administration has a notch for a launch date of April 17, with backup dates April 18 through 21, in its Operations Plan Advisory document; Starship has been fully stacked on the pad at its Starbase facility at Boca Chica, Texas, and the company is planning a launch rehearsal next week followed by the first integrated flight test approximately a week later; It's unclear if Starship will enter orbit, then immediately perform a deorbit burn to splash down, or if it is a long suborbital flight.

item.title: Show HN: Building musical synthesizers with SQL queries
item.description: A GitHub repository called NoiSQL enables musical sound generation with SQL queries, using basic waves, oscillators, sequencers, LFOs, and noise generators.

item.title: The longest straight line in Great Britain without crossing a public road
item.description: A longer straight line has been found in Great Britain without crossing a public road than the one identified by Ordnance Survey in 2019.

item.title: Flipper Zero banned by Amazon for being a 'card skimming device'
item.description: Amazon has banned the sale of Flipper Zero on its platform, blaming it as a "card skimming device."

item.title: Reverse Engineering the Facebook Messenger API
item.description: The author reverse-engineered the Facebook Messenger API to create Messyger, a command-line program.

item.title: The machines of Tatjana van Vark
item.description: Tatjana van Vark, an independent researcher from the Netherlands, has built, replicated, and restored a wide variety of scientific instruments.

item.title: Big Ball of Mud (1999)
item.description: The article explores the BIG BALL OF MUD software architecture and why it persists despite high-minded approaches.

item.title: NSA created online cybersecurity course with 100s of classes
item.description: The NSA has created an online cybersecurity course with hundreds of classes available.

item.title: Replacing bad systems with bad systems
item.description: In his blog post, Seth uses the metaphor of outdated parking meters to illustrate the need to rethink and improve bad systems.

item.title: Neovim 0.9
item.description: Neovim version 0.9.0 has been released, featuring changes to iconv, libintl, optional params, lua2dox, semantic tokens, '+tui', Yarn node modules support, and code block highlighting.

item.title: Direct evidence of the use of multiple drugs in Bronze Age from human hair test
item.description: A study found direct evidence of multiple psychoactive plant species in Bronze Age Menorca using human hair analysis.

item.title: NYPD officers brag about milking overtime in accidental recording
item.description: An accidental recording made during the arrest of a construction worker has exposed police officers bragging about "milking overtime" and using derogatory language towards detainees.

item.title: Show HN: ChatGDB â€“ GPT-Powered GDB Assistant
item.description: ChatGDB is a tool that enhances the debugging experience in GDB by using the power of ChatGPT, allowing natural language commands to be executed automatically.
